Line 43: Line 43:
At the same time as the announcement of the formation of the Open Handset Alliance on 5 November 2007, the OHA also unveiled [[Android (operating system)|Android]], an [[open source]] [[mobile phone]] [[platform (computing)|platform]] based on the [[Linux]] kernel.<ref name=AndroidAnnouce/> An early look at the [[SDK]] was released to developers on 12 November 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.openhandsetalliance.com/developers.html|title=Developers|date=2007-11-05|accessdate=2007-11-05|publisher=Open Handset Alliance}}</ref>
At the same time as the announcement of the formation of the Open Handset Alliance on 5 November 2007, the OHA also unveiled [[Android (operating system)|Android]], an [[open source]] [[mobile phone]] [[platform (computing)|platform]] based on the [[Linux]] kernel.<ref name=AndroidAnnouce/> An early look at the [[SDK]] was released to developers on 12 November 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.openhandsetalliance.com/developers.html|title=Developers|date=2007-11-05|accessdate=2007-11-05|publisher=Open Handset Alliance}}</ref>
â
The first commercially available phone running Android was the [[T-Mobile G1]] (also known as the HTC Dream). It was approved by the [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) on 18 August 2008,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.engadget.com/2008/08/18/htc-dream-fcc-approved-android-clear-for-launch/|title=FCC Approved HTC Dream|date=2008-08-18|publisher=Engadget}}</ref> and became available on 22 October.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=94982690|title=Google Is Calling. Will You Answer?}}</ref>
+
The first commercially available phone running Android was the [[HTC Dream]] (also known as the T-Mobile G1). It was approved by the [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) on 18 August 2008,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.engadget.com/2008/08/18/htc-dream-fcc-approved-android-clear-for-launch/|title=FCC Approved HTC Dream|date=2008-08-18|publisher=Engadget}}</ref> and became available on 22 October.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=94982690|title=Google Is Calling. Will You Answer?}}</ref>
